subject: Re: [junit] Simplified exception handling in tests
msgSnippet: I suggest you to simply add throws Exception to your test method signature. Nice and easy. ;) Manuel ... e.toString() ... e.toString() ... e.toString() ...
messageBody:
I suggest you to simply add "throws Exception" to your test method
signature. Nice and easy. ;)

Manuel

--------------- On 04/04/2003 10:36:13 AM John Lindwall wrote:
---------------
> Here's a snippet of code from one of our unit tests:
>
> try {
> ClientSBHome home = (ClientSBHome) getEJBHome( jndiName,
>ClientSBHome.class );
> sessionBean = home.create();
> } catch( NamingException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " +
e.toString()
>);
> } catch( CreateException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " +
e.toString()
>);
> } catch( RemoteException e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " +
e.toString()
>);
> }
>
>All three exceptions are considered failures -- no special handling of
any. My
>inclination is to simplify this code by collapsing the catch blocks into
one.
>Comments?
>
> try {
> ClientSBHome home = (ClientSBHome) getEJBHome( jndiName,
>ClientSBHome.class );
> sessionBean = home.create();
> } catch( Exception e ) {
> fail( "Cannot get Client session bean from server: " +
e.toString()
>);
> }
